head.title: The Great Cover-Up: Hide Those Weeds

hedline.hl1: The Great Cover-Up: Hide Those Weeds

block.p: Most hands-on gardeners have a dirty little secret, and it's hiding under the shrubs. The secret is weeds, self-sown tree seedlings, and poison ivy, all of which have a habit of springing up, especially after a rainy spell.
The problem is that this unwanted vegetation is thoroughly camouflaged and usually goes unnoticed until it is well-rooted.

Most hands-on gardeners have a dirty little secret, and it's hiding under the shrubs. The secret is weeds, self-sown tree seedlings, and poison ivy, all of which have a habit of springing up, especially after a rainy spell.
The problem is that this unwanted vegetation is thoroughly camouflaged and usually goes unnoticed until it is well-rooted.

To stop trouble before it starts, you can do one of two things: plant a ground cover under the shrubs, or cover the earth with a layer of newspaper or landscaping fabric topped with a layer of decorative mulch. Hosta makes an effective player in under-the-shrub scenes. For something closer to the ground, try a good-natured low-lying plant such as Lamium. A creeping groundcover beats a garden thug every time.
